questions.text: What is the most likely stage of TB hip in a female with left leg shortening?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Stage 3

Explanation:

  • Stage 3 is characterized by significant destruction of the articular surface of the hip joint. In this stage, true shortening of the leg occurs due to the destruction and deformity of the joint structure.

 

Babulkar and Pandey Clinico-Radiological Classification

Stage

Clinical Findings

X-ray findings

Stage I: Synovitis (Option A)
  • Irritable hip
  • Increased FABER (Flexion, Abduction, External Rotation)
  • Apparent lengthening due to FABER (Position of ease due to synovitis)
  • Terminal movements are restricted by 25%

Normal or haziness of the articular margins

Stage II: Early Arthritis (Option B)

 
  • Early joint pain, stiffness
  • Increased FADIR (Flexion, Adduction, Internal Rotation)
  • Apparent shortening due to FADIR
  • Gluteal and Quadriceps muscle wasting
  • ROM restricted by 50%

Osteopenia and narrowing of joint space

Stage III: Late Arthritis (Option C)
  • Marked FADIR
  • True shortening
  • Gross restriction of movements (usually >50%)

Marked subchondral erosion and destruction

Stage IV: Pathological Dislocation/severe arthritis (Option D )
  • Marked FADIR
  • Gross shortening
  • Severe destruction and loss of joint space
  • "Wandering/traveling Acetabulum": Pathological dislocation/subluxation due to gross destruction of the femoral head or the superior acetabular margin.
  • End stage of TB hip/arthritis: Fibrous ankylosis
  • End stage of TB spine: Bony ankylosis

questions.text: Identifying finding seen in TB knee is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Reduction of joint space

Explanation:

  • Joint space reduction is the characteristic finding in TB knee.

T.B. of Knee Joint:

  • Third common site of skeletal TB infection
  • The initial lesion formation is seen in Synovium (Last in Hip joint)

Stages:

  • Synovitis:Boggy swelling and pain
  • Early Arthritis
  • Late Arthritis or Pathological dislocation: Triple deformity
  • Flexion of knee: It is due to Hamstring spasm
  • Posterior subluxation of tibia:Due to Laxity of capsule
  • Lateral shift of tibia: Due to spasm of ilio-tibial band
  • External rotation of tibia: Due to spasm of ilio-tibial band

Treatment:

  • ATT (2HRZS + 7HR)
  • Traction
  • For early arthritis, along with ATT, Synovectomy and Joint debridement/Joint clearance can opt.

For pathological dislocation:

  • ATT
  • Arthrodesis (fusing of joint)
  • Total knee replacement

questions.text: Identifying finding seen in TB knee is
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option: A

Tuberculosis of the knee, also known as tuberculous arthritis or Pott's disease of the knee, is a form of extrapulmonary tuberculosis that affects the knee joint. In this condition, the tuberculosis bacteria infect the synovial lining of the knee joint, leading to inflammation, destruction of joint structures, and subsequent reduction of the joint space.

Incorrect options:

Option B. Increase in joint space: Tuberculosis of the knee typically leads to destruction and narrowing of the joint space rather than an increase. This is due to the destructive nature of the infection, which can erode the articular cartilage and other joint structures.

Option C. Degeneration of cartilage: While the destruction of joint structures, including cartilage, is a characteristic feature of tuberculosis of the knee, it does not manifest as degeneration in the sense of wear-and-tear or age-related changes. Rather, it is the result of the direct effects of the tuberculosis infection on the joint.

Option D. none of the above this option is incorrect

questions.text: Assertion: As Pott's spine progresses and causes neurological difficulties, decompression surgery becomes necessary.  Why: Neurological abnormalities may persist even after completion of ATT.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is true, but the reason is false
Assertion is false, but the reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.solution:
Correct Option is B: Both the assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion.

  • Assertion: Decompression surgery is needed with progressive neurological difficulty in Pott's spine. This means that when there is a progressive neurological impairment in Pott's spine (spinal tuberculosis), decompression surgery is necessary.
  • Reason: Even after completion of ATT (anti-tuberculosis treatment), there can be neurological abnormalities. This statement is true, as some patients may still experience residual neurological deficits even after completing the anti-tuberculosis treatment.

Incorrect options:

Option A: This option states that both the assertion and reason are true, and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion. However, as explained earlier, the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion.

Option C: This option states that the assertion is true, but the reason is false. However, both the assertion and reason are true, so this option is incorrect.

Option D: This option states that the assertion is false, but the reason is false. However, the assertion is true, so this option is incorrect.

Option E: This option states that both the assertion and reason are false. However, as explained earlier, both the assertion and reason are true, so this option is incorrect.

questions.text: According to WHO, which of the following is the recommended diagnostic test for spinal tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Culture and Sensitivity

Explanation:

  • According to the World Health Organization (WHO), the recommended and definitive diagnostic test for spinal tuberculosis is Culture and Sensitivity.
  • Spinal tuberculosis, also known as Pott’s disease, is a form of extrapulmonary TB that primarily affects the vertebral column.
  • Diagnosing spinal TB is more complex than pulmonary TB because it typically involves deeper tissues and presents with nonspecific symptoms like chronic back pain, fever, weight loss, and neurological deficits in advanced stages.
  • WHO strongly recommends CB-NAAT as a first-line test for extrapulmonary TB, including spinal TB, because it gives results within hours and helps initiate treatment quickly.
  • However, due to its certain limitations, it cannot replace culture as the definitive test. (Option C)

Imaging used for diagnosing Pott’s spine:

MRI:

  • Investigation of choice to evaluate the type and extent of compression of the cord.
  • IOC for potts spine and potts paraplegia.
  • But doesn't help to visualize bony vertebral destruction.
  • Earlier signs, spinal nerve root, and paraspinal soft tissue are better visualized.
  • The best diagnostic modality for spinal TB.

CT scan: (Option B)

  • The most preferred imaging modality for the assessment of destruction of the vertebral body and sequestrum formation.
  • The pattern of bone damage, including fragmentary, osteolytic, sclerotic, and subperiosteal changes, is clearly visible on CT scans.

X-ray: (Option A)

  • is useful as an initial imaging tool, but it lacks sensitivity and may miss early disease.
  • Findings are:
    • Reduction of disc space- Lateral X-ray is better for the evaluation of disc space.
    • In the early stages- wedging of the vertebrae.
    • In late stages- angular kyphotic deformity.
    • Evidence of cold abscess:
      • Bird nest appearance of cold abscess of the thoracic region showing typical fusiform shape.
    • Rarefaction: There is diffuse rarefaction of the vertebrae above and below the lesion.
    • Types of lesions in the vertebral column are:
      • Paradiscal (most common)
      • Central
      • Anterior
      • Posterior ( pedicle, lamina, spinous process, and transverse process)
    • Signs of healing:
      • Sclerosis
      • Sclerotic bone
      • Bony fusion
